channel.title: Reuters: World News
channel.description: Reuters.com is your source for breaking news, business, financial and investing news, including personal finance and stocks. Reuters is the leading global provider of news, financial information and technology solutions to the world's media, financial institutions, businesses and individuals.

item.title: Sweden heads for minority left government, far right surges
item.description: STOCKHOLM (Reuters) - Sweden's centre-left Social Democrat leader Stefan Lofven emerged as victor in Sunday's general election after a voter backlash against tax cuts and trimmed welfare by a centre-right government, but he fell short of a parliamentary majority.

item.title: Ex-president Gbagbo's party withdraws from Ivory Coast poll body
item.description: ABIDJAN (Reuters) - The party of former Ivory Coast President Laurent Gbagbo withdrew from the country's election commission on Sunday, setting back efforts to draw it into the political mainstream before a scheduled presidential election next year.

item.title: Many deaths as boat with African emigrants sinks off Libyan coast - Libya navy
item.description: BENGHAZI Libya (Reuters) - A boat packed with up to 250 African emigrants trying to reach European shores sank on Sunday off the Libyan coast and most are feared dead, a spokesman for the Libyan navy said.

item.title: Sweden left heads for election victory, short of majority
item.description: STOCKHOLM (Reuters) - Sweden's centre-left opposition headed for an election victory on Sunday but fell short of a parliamentary majority, the first election projection showed, as voters backed increased spending on job schemes, schools and hospitals after eight years of tax cuts and trimmed welfare under the centre-right Alliance.

item.title: With eye on China, Modi's India to develop disputed border region
item.description: NEW DELHI (Reuters) - India has eased restrictions on building roads and military facilities along its disputed border with China, as the new government seeks to close the gap on its neighbour's superior transport network and take a stronger stance on Beijing.

item.title: Libyan PM accuses Qatar of sending planes with weapons to Tripoli
item.description: CAIRO (Reuters) - Libyan Prime Minister Abdullah al-Thinni said on Sunday Qatar had sent three military planes loaded with weapons and ammunition to a Tripoli airport controlled by an armed opposition group.

item.title: North Korea sentences U.S. citizen Matthew Miller to six years hard labour
item.description: SEOUL (Reuters) - North Korea sentenced U.S. citizen Matthew Todd Miller to six years hard labour for committing "hostile acts" as a tourist to the country, a statement carried by state media said on Sunday, as the United States requested his immediate pardon and release.

item.title: Germany's eurosceptic AfD surges to win seats in two states
item.description: BERLIN (Reuters) - Germany's eurosceptic Alternative for Germany (AfD) party surged to win more than 10 percent of the vote in two states on Sunday in a growing challenge to Chancellor Angela Merkel as her new right-wing rival makes further inroads into her power base.

item.title: Uganda seizes explosives, suicide vests from suspected al Shabaab cell
item.description: KAMPALA (Reuters) - Police in the Ugandan capital Kampala seized "substantial amounts of explosives" and suicide vests in raids on a suspected al Shabaab cell that was planning an imminent attack, a Ugandan official said in an interview on Sunday.

item.title: Mali landmine kills U.N. peacekeeper, wounds four others
item.description: BAMAKO (Reuters) - A landmine explosion hit a vehicle carrying U.N. peacekeepers from Chad on patrol in northeastern Mali on Sunday, killing one and seriously wounding four others, the U.N. mission in Mali said.

item.title: White House seeks to win over sceptics on Islamic State fight
item.description: WASHINGTON (Reuters) - A top White House aide on Sunday defended President Barack Obama's plan to fight Islamic State militants, as the administration sought to persuade the U.S. Congress to back an escalation of the effort.

item.title: U.S. sees Middle East help fighting IS, Britain cautious after beheading
item.description: WASHINGTON/LONDON (Reuters) - Washington said countries in the Middle East had offered to join air strikes against Islamic State militants and Australia said it would send troops, but Britain held back even after the group beheaded a British hostage and threatened to kill another.

item.title: Kerry says some nations offer ground troops to fight Islamic State
item.description: WASHINGTON (Reuters) - U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry said he was "extremely encouraged" by pledges of military assistance against Islamic State militants by countries inside and outside the Middle East and that some nations had offered ground troops.

item.title: Cameron resists calls for air strikes despite hostage killing
item.description: LONDON/EDINBURGH (Reuters) - Britain resisted pressure on Sunday to join the United States in announcing air strikes against Islamic State after the militant group beheaded David Haines, a British hostage, and threatened to kill another Briton.

item.title: NATO countries have begun arms deliveries to Ukraine - defence minister
item.description: KIEV (Reuters) - Ukraine's defence minister said on Sunday that NATO countries were delivering weapons to his country to equip it to fight pro-Russian separatists and "stop" Russian President Vladimir Putin.

item.title: Fresh sanctions will freeze big foreign oil projects in Russia
item.description: By Olesya Astakhova, Katya Golubkova and Vladimir Soldatkin

item.title: At a landmark Berlin rally, Merkel vows to fight anti-Semitism
item.description: BERLIN (Reuters) - Germany will do all it can to fight anti-Semitism, Chancellor Angela Merkel said in a speech on Sunday, following a surge of abuse against Jews and spreading anti-Israeli sentiment aroused by the Gaza conflict.

item.title: Al Qaeda denies decline, acknowledges 'mistakes' by its branches
item.description: (Reuters) - Al Qaeda dismissed as "lies" a U.S. assessment that it is in decline, but a defiant online message issued by the network on Sunday made no mention of the ultra-hardline Islamic State group widely seen as its rival for the leadership of global jihad.

item.title: A week on from flood, 150,000 still stranded in Indian Kashmir
item.description: SRINAGAR, India (Reuters) - About 150,000 people were still stranded in their homes a week after Indian Kashmir's worst flood in over a century and fears grew on Sunday of an outbreak of diseases from vast fields of stagnant brown water.

item.title: Post-war counselling awaits Gaza children going back to school
item.description: GAZA (Reuters) - Some 500,000 children returned on Sunday to school in the Gaza Strip, where many will be given psychological counselling before regular studies begin after a devastating 50-day war between Palestinian militants and Israel.

item.title: Deaths from Nigeria church guest house collapse rise to 41
item.description: LAGOS (Reuters) - The number of people killed in the collapse of a guest house under construction at the Lagos headquarters of one of Nigeria's best-known Christian evangelical pastors rose to 41 on Sunday, rescuers said, as they worked to clear the wreckage.

item.title: Uganda arrests 19 tied to suspected attack plot
item.description: KAMPALA (Reuters) - Ugandan police have arrested 19 people in connection with a foiled attack in central Kampala that the United States has said was hatched by Somali militants al Shabaab.

item.title: Sweden votes with centre-left opposition holding narrow lead
item.description: STOCKHOLM (Reuters) - Polls showed Sweden's centre-left opposition heading for a narrow election victory on Sunday, on a platform of increased spending on job schemes, healthcare and schools after eight years of tax cuts under the centre-right Alliance.

item.title: Typhoon Kalmaegi slams northern Philippines, cuts power lines
item.description: MANILA (Reuters) - A strong typhoon slammed into the rice-producing Philippine northern region on Sunday, cutting power and communications lines and forcing people to flee to higher ground, national disaster agency officials said.

item.title: Islamic State attracts female jihadis from U.S. heartland
item.description: MINNEAPOLIS (Reuters) - U.S. law enforcement is investigating a new phenomenon of women from the American heartland joining Islamic State as President Barack Obama vows to cut off the militants' recruiting at home.
